During the night of 5â6 February, some protesters continued to camp out in Tahrir Square, while Alexandria also had peaceful late night protests. However, gunfire rang out in the early hours of the day in Cairo.<ref name="aljazlive"/> The same organisers of the "Day of Anger", "Friday of Anger", "March of the Millions" and "Friday of Departure" called for a protest all over Egypt on 5 February, which was dubbed the "'''Sunday of martyrs'''" ({{lang-ar|Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ø§ÙØ´ÙØ¯Ø§Ø¡}}).
During the night of 5â6 February, some protesters continued to camp out in Tahrir Square, while Alexandria also had peaceful late night protests. However, gunfire rang out in the early hours of the day in Cairo.<ref name="aljazlive"/> The same organisers of the "Day of Anger", "Friday of Anger", "March of the Millions" and "Friday of Departure" called for a protest all over Egypt on 5 February, which was dubbed the "'''Sunday of martyrs'''" ({{lang-ar|Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ø§ÙØ´ÙØ¯Ø§Ø¡}}).
â
Egyptian Christians were scheduled to hold a mass in Tahrir Square in Cairo on Sunday in order to counter claims by state television that most of the anti-Mubarak protesters are members of the Muslim Brotherhood. The Coptic Christians wanted to show that they are part of Egypt's popular uprising and share the same grievances as the rest of the country's people.
+
Egyptian Christians held a hold a mass in Tahrir Square in Cairo on Sunday in order to counter claims by state television that most of the anti-Mubarak protesters are members of the Muslim Brotherhood. The Coptic Christians wanted to show that they are part of Egypt's popular uprising and share the same grievances as the rest of the country's people. Later muslims participated in ''Salat al-Janazah'' ({{lang-ar|'''ØµÙØ§Ø© Ø§ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ø²Ø©'''}}).
